clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Study of Connected Diabetes Technology
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study of Connected Diabetes Technology

brief_summary.textblock: To test the hypothesis that remote sharing of health data - including measured blood glucose values as well as patient-reported carbohydrate counts and insulin doses - with the UC Davis Pediatric Diabetes team via connected health applications is feasible for pediatric patients with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Use of applications to share data

primary_outcome.description: Parent reported survey to determine how often families review blood sugar numbers and the ease of use of the applications.
Parent reported survey to determine how often families review blood sugar numbers and the ease of use of the applications.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At each clinic visit until 6 months since diagnosis
secondary_outcome.description: How often patients are monitoring their blood sugar (documented in electronic medical record)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At each clinic visit until 6 months since diagnosis
secondary_outcome.description: Hemoglobin A1c values collected at each clinic visit (documented in electronic medical record)

arm_group.description: Participants will be asked to use applications to track food intake, carbohydrate counts, insulin delivered, and blood sugar values and share the data with the study team.

The control group will receive usual care during their hospitalizations at the time of diabetes diagnosis, and during the time between hospital discharge and first visit to the UCD Pediatric Diabetes clinic.

intervention.description: Use applications after initial diagnosis to share information with study team.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newly diagnosed with T1D in the past 6 weeks
- Daily access to the internet via a wireless connection
Exclusion Criteria:
- Does not plan to attend the UC Davis Pediatric Endocrinology clinic for future diabetes care
- Primary caregiver does not speak English
